title-group.article-title: Governance Structure Changes and Product Market Competition: Evidence from U.S. Electric Utility Deregulation*

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2006 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: Electric utility deregulation associated with the 1992 Energy Policy Act represents a natural experiment for observing linkages between governance structure changes and product market competition. This study finds that governance structures of utilities are enhanced in their ability to control owner‐manager agency conflict post‐1992, but not by as much as comparable industrial firms. Incomplete utility deregulation leads to competition increases that are not as great as those of industrial firms. Governance structure enhancements of utilities lag behind those of industrial firms. Further deregulation is expected to stimulate competition, leading to governance structures that provide greater control of owner‐manager agency conflict.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The empirical corporate governance literature shows that deregulation tends to be accompanied by governance structure changes that are consistent with greater control of owner‐manager agency conflict (Crawford, Ezzell, and Miles1995; Hubbard and Palia1995; Bryan, Hwang, and Thomas1997; Kole and Lehn1997,1999; Bryan, Hwang, and Lilien1999). However, it is not clear why regulatory oversight reductions lead to governance structure changes. One possibility is that reduced regulatory supervision following deregulation leads firms to adopt governance structures that better control owner‐manager agency conflict. Governance structures could be strengthened through greater managerial or blockholder ownership concentration, closer alignment of manager‐owner incentives, or smaller or more independent boards. Another possibility is that reduced regulatory interference with market forces following deregulation leads managers to compete with existing firms and new entrants. Managers can respond to increased competition by making decisions that maximize firm value to ensure organizational and thus their own survival, reducing the need for costly governance structures to control owner‐manager agency conflict. The distinction between reduced regulatory oversight and product market competition sets the stage for a demonstration that increased product market competition stemming from reduced regulatory supervision explains observed changes in the governance structures of firms.

In this paper, I employ U.S. electric utility deregulation as a natural experiment to investigate the association between governance structure changes and product market competition. I have two objectives in the paper. The first is to explain what changes occur in the governance structures of electric utilities following deregulation. This is achieved by examining changes, and trend‐adjusted changes, in the governance structure characteristics of deregulating electric utilities. The second is to explore the relation between governance structure changes and product market competition. This is accomplished by regressing governance structure characteristics that change on product market competition, controlling for temporal changes in the severity of regulatory supervision. In the process, the paper shows that product market competition complements governance structures in controlling owner‐manager agency conflict.

The test sample consists of 101 U.S. electric utilities and 101 U.S. industrial firms matched to utilities on size, prior performance, and age, during the periods 1987 and 1990 (the prederegulation period) and 1994 and 1997 (the postderegulation period). Individual governance characteristics include proportions of chief executive officer (CEO), officer and director, and outside blockholder ownership; values of CEO pay and option grants; the proportion of CEO option grants to total CEO pay; board size; and the proportion of outside directors on boards. In the first part of the analysis, I identify changes and trend‐adjusted changes in each of these governance characteristics and two overall measures of the ability of governance structures to control owner‐manager agency conflict. Overall governance measures are constructed by applying factor analysis to the individual governance characteristics of firms that change, or exhibit trend‐adjusted change, and by multiplying resulting factor weights by firm‐year data. In the second part of the analysis, I identify relations between each of product market competition and regulatory monitoring and individual and overall measures of governance characteristics of firms. Product market competition is estimated using the Herfindahl‐Hirschman index of industry concentration. Temporal changes in regulatory supervision are estimated by applying factor analysis to electric utility regulation variables and generating regulatory supervision scores. Finally, I explore how product market competition and regulatory monitoring vary over time and between utilities and industrial firms.

The evidence in this paper shows that electric utilities enhance their governance structures after deregulation, but not by as much as comparable industrial firms. Specifically, electric utilities increase proportions of CEO and outside blockholder ownership, CEO pay in options, and outside directors on boards and reduce board size. These changes suggest that governance structures better control owner‐manager agency conflict after deregulation, consistent with prior evidence on the effects of deregulation in the airline industry (Kole and Lehn1997,1999). However, the paper also shows that the proportions of outside blockholder ownership and CEO pay in options increase less, and board size decreases less, for utilities than for industrial firms. These changes suggest that utilities do not strengthen their governance structures as much as industrial firms, reinforcing some of the evidence on the trend‐adjusted effects of airline deregulation in Kole and Lehn (1999).1

More important, this paper shows that increases in product market competition resulting from reduced regulatory monitoring explain observed changes in governance structures. Product market competition is associated with greater proportions of CEO ownership and outside directors on boards, and smaller boards, for utilities. However, product market competition is also associated with relatively smaller proportions of outside blockholder ownership and CEO pay in options, and larger boards, for utilities compared to industrial firms. Partial electric utility deregulation associated with the Energy Policy Act leads to competition increases for utilities that are not as substantial as those experienced by industrial firms. Changes in governance structures of utilities provide greater control of owner‐manager agency conflict but do not keep pace with those of industrial firms. This finding leads me to conclude that further deregulation of electric utilities will likely further stimulate competition, resulting in governance structures that provide even greater control over owner‐manager agency conflict.

fn.p: Kole and Lehn (1999) show that deregulating airlines do not increase the proportion of outside directors on boards as much as industrial firms, suggesting weaker governance structure control of owner‐manager agency conflict. However, they also find that deregulating airlines increase outside blockholder ownership and reduce board size more than industrial firms, suggesting stronger governance. Their trend‐adjusted results are therefore mixed.

sec.label: II.
sec.title: Prior Literature and Hypotheses
sec.p: In this section, I motivate the study by reviewing prior literature on external pressure, governance structures, and deregulation. I also identify testable hypotheses and predictions.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Motivation
sec.p: Product market competition potentially disciplines managers, as suggested by Fama (1980) and Jensen (1986). Using a Herfindahl‐Hirschman index as a proxy for industry concentration, Chevalier (1995) shows that leverage is associated with predatory pricing and DeFond and Park (1999) show that CEO turnover is higher for firms in competitive industries. Competition could also affect ownership, compensation, and board characteristics of firms.

Regulatory supervision can affect governance in two ways. First, regulators monitor managers, effectively reducing monitoring costs normally incurred by shareholders, as suggested by Jensen and Meckling (1976) and Demsetz and Lehn (1985). Regulation limits growth opportunities, simplifying managerial performance evaluation, as noted by Smith and Watts (1992). Regulators also discourage executive stock option compensation and constrain CEO pay for political reasons, as shown by Joskow, Rose, and Shepard (1993) and Joskow, Rose, and Wolfram (1996). Second, regulation transfers owner‐manager agency costs to ratepayers. Regulators approve rates of return that include costs plus a “fair” return on capital under rate of return regulation common in the electric utility industry. Under pure rate of return regulation, all costs, including agency costs, are passed on to the consumer, and the owner‐manager agency problem disappears, as shown in Kole and Lehn (1999). Pure rate of return regulation rarely exists in practice, since many utilities are also subject to incentive regulation, where specific operating targets are set by regulators and penalties are imposed if targets are not met. Some costs are sometimes disallowed, giving rise to “stranded costs.” Both possibilities imply that deregulation increases the need for governance structures to control owner‐manager agency conflict.

Takeover activity is another potential source of external pressure on managers, as suggested by Manne (1965), Alchian and Demsetz (1972), Fama (1980), and Jensen (1986). Takeover activity can be estimated using dummy variables such as those representing states that do not restrict bank takeovers through statute, as in Schranz (1993), or active versus inactive takeover markets, as in Mikkelson and Partch (1997). Banks tend to adopt governance structures that better control owner‐manager agency conflict when takeover markets are inactive, as shown by Schranz. CEO turnover following poor performance is more likely in active takeover markets, as shown by Mikkelson and Partch. The literature suggests that takeovers discipline managers, possibly also affecting governance structures.

Governance structures are commonly examined in the literature as batteries of ownership, CEO compensation, and board structure characteristics of firms. Ownership structure directly affects owner‐manager agency conflict, as noted by Jensen and Meckling (1976), Demsetz and Lehn (1985), Stulz (1990), and Himmelberg, Hubbard, and Palia (1999). This research suggests that firms with higher concentrations of CEO, officer and director or outside blockholder ownership possess governance structures that better control owner‐manager agency conflict.2Executive compensation influences owner‐manager agency conflict, as noted by Jensen and Murphy (1990), Smith and Watts (1992), and Mehran (1995). Greater proportions of CEO stock option grants to total CEO pay more closely align CEO and shareholder interests, reducing owner‐manager agency conflict. Board structure affects owner‐manager agency problems, as suggested by Fama and Jensen (1983), Weisbach (1988), Hermalin and Weisbach (1991), Jensen (1993), Yermack (1996), and Rosenstein and Wyatt (1997). Smaller boards and boards with greater proportions of outside to total directors are believed to better monitor managers.

Deregulation affects at least some of the governance characteristics of banks, electric utilities, and airlines. CEO pay performance sensitivity increases following interstate banking deregulation, as shown in Crawford et al. (1995) and Hubbard and Palia (1995). CEO pay, options, and pay performance sensitivity tend to be higher for firms facing less intensive regulatory supervision, as noted by Bryan, Hwang, and Thomas (1997) and Bryan, Hwang, and Lilien (1999). Deregulating airlines tend to gradually adopt governance structures that resemble those of nonregulated industrial firms, as shown in Kole and Lehn (1999). Kole and Lehn show that airline deregulation is followed by increased equity ownership concentration, higher CEO pay, greater use of CEO stock options, and smaller boards, suggesting that deregulation is a catalyst that moves firms toward governance structures that better control owner‐manager agency conflict. However, they find that deregulating airlines increase outside blockholder ownership concentration and reduce board size more than industrial firms, suggesting stronger trend‐adjusted governance, but do not increase proportions of outside directors as much as industrial firms, suggesting weaker trend‐adjusted governance. Kole and Lehn acknowledge that product market competition increases after deregulation but do not differentiate between the effects of reduced regulation and increased competition on governance structures in their multivariate analysis.

fn.p: Alternatively, outside blockholders could be viewed as external. Morck, Shleifer, and Vishny (1988) also note that a nonmonotonic relation exists between ownership and agency conflict. To be consistent with Kole and Lehn (1999), I treat outside blockholders as integral parts of the firm and assume a monotonic negative relation between ownership concentration and owner‐manager agency conflict.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Testable Hypotheses and Predictions
sec.p: The two objectives of this paper correspond to its two hypotheses. The first hypothesis, which I refer to as thederegulation effect hypothesis, states that deregulation is accompanied by changes, and trend‐adjusted changes, in utility governance structures consistent with greater control of owner‐manager agency conflict. Governance changes consistent with stronger control include higher CEO, officer and director, or blockholder ownership concentration, greater proportions of CEO stock option grants to total CEO pay, smaller boards, and boards with greater proportions of outside directors. Consistent with the prior literature, I expect to see increases in real CEO pay and option compensation following deregulation. Overall governance structure changes consistent with greater control of owner‐manager agency conflict will include a preponderance of individual governance characteristic changes in the direction of greater control of owner‐manager agency conflict, or higher governance index scores.

Empirical support for the deregulation effect hypothesis implies that deregulation reduces monitoring by regulators, leading firms to adopt governance structures that better align owner‐manager interests, improve board effectiveness, or make boards more independent. Evidence from tests of this hypothesis will improve our understanding of the relation between changes in governance structures and deregulation, in fulfillment of the first objective of the paper.

The second hypothesis, which I term theproduct market competition effect hypothesis, claims that electric utility deregulation introduces product market competition that pressures utilities to adopt governance structures that provide greater control of owner‐manager agency conflict. Activist shareholders can exert pressures for the adoption of governance structures to better control owner‐manager agency conflict. In this scenario, competition and governance structures that control agency conflict will be complements. Alternatively, managers can respond to competition by making decisions that maximize firm value to ensure organizational and thus their own survival, reducing the need for governance structures to control owner‐manager agency conflict. In this case, product market competition and governance structures that mitigate owner‐manager agency problems will be substitutes. Moreover, competition could simply be unrelated to agency conflict, as suggested by Jensen and Meckling (1976).

Empirical support for the product market competition effect hypothesis suggests that deregulation reduces regulatory supervision, leading to increased competition and governance changes. Evidence from tests of this hypothesis will provide insight into the relation between product market competition and governance structure, meeting the second objective of the paper.

sec.label: III.
sec.title: Sample Selection, Variables, Data, and Methodology

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Sample Selection
sec.p: The primary sample consists of 101 publicly traded U.S. investor‐owned electric utilities listed in Compustat under Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) codes 4911 (electric services) and 4931 (electric and other services combined).3Publicly traded investor‐owned utilities account for 80% of industry capacity and revenues. Of 145 such firms, 18 are excluded because they are foreign, 10 because of non‐December fiscal year ends, and 16 because they could not be matched to industrial firms on prior performance, size, and age. No sample utilities went bankrupt during the test period, and only one was the target of takeover activity.

The control sample consists of 101 publicly traded U.S. industrial firms listed in Compustat under SIC codes 2000–3999. Consistent with the prior literature, I avoid problems associated with financial firms, and regulated firms from industries other than electric utilities, by focusing on industrial firms. Individual industrial firms are matched to electric utilities on size (90%–110% of prior year market value of assets), prior performance (closest prior five‐year average return on assets), and age (the firm must have been publicly traded at least since December 31, 1981). By matching on size and prior performance, I control for potential bias related to the mean reversion of accounting measures (Barber and Lyon1996; Kothari and Warner1997). The restriction on firm age helps control for potential effects of differences in governance structures between young and old firms.

The test period covers 1987 and 1990 (the prederegulation period) and 1994 and 1997 (the postderegulation period). These years correspond to five and two years before, and two and five years after, passage of the 1992 Energy Policy Act. Financial and stock price data are taken from Compustat and the Center for Research in Security Prices (CRSP) and governance data from Q‐data proxy statements. Stock option grant values are estimated by applying the Black and Scholes (1973) option pricing model, adjusted for dividends, excluding pension contributions, to CRSP and proxy statement data (see Kole1997). The primary sample consists of 178 utility firm‐year observations for the prederegulation period and 141 for the postderegulation period. The control sample contains 152 industrial firm‐year observations for the prederegulation period and 128 for the postderegulation period.

fn.p: SIC 4911 includes “establishments engaged in the generation, transmission, and/or distribution of electric energy for sale,” and SIC 4931 includes “establishments primarily engaged in providing electric services in combination with other services, with electric services as the major part though less than 95% of the total” (Occupational Safety and Health Administration, U.S. Department of Labor). The prior literature also commonly defines the U.S. electric utility industry as SICs 4911 and 4931 (Bryan, Hwang, and Thomas1997; Bryan, Hwang, and Lilien1999; Kole and Lehn1999).

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Variables
sec.p: I examine three financial characteristics of firms in this paper. Firm size (Size) is measured as the market value of total assets, expressed in millions of 1997 constant dollars. Leverage (Lev) is the inverse of the interest coverage ratio, where interest coverage is earnings before interest and tax plus depreciation, all scaled by interest expense. Growth opportunities (MTB) are measured as the market to book ratio, with the numerator total assets less book value of equity plus the product of year end stock price and the number of shares outstanding, and the denominator book value of assets.

I focus on eight governance characteristics of firms. CEO ownership is the proportion of equity outstanding held by the CEO, expressed as a percentage. Officer and director ownership is the proportion of equity outstanding held by officers and directors, expressed as a percentage. Outside blockholder ownership is the proportion of equity outstanding held by outside blockholders (unaffiliated parties who own at least 5% of the common shares of the firm), expressed as a percentage. CEO compensation is total CEO pay, including cash, bonus, and current‐year restricted stock and option grants, where option grants are estimated using the Black and Scholes (1973) option pricing model, adjusted for dividends, excluding pension contributions, and expressed in millions of 1997 constant dollars. CEO options are the option grant component of CEO compensation. CEO options as a proportion of pay represents the value of stock option grants scaled by total CEO pay. Board size is the number of directors on the board. Outside directors is the proportion of directors who are outside directors (directors who were never managers or relatives of managers of the firm and have no other material business relationships with the firm).

Other variables used include dummy variables for deregulation and industry that are set equal to one if the observation is post‐1992 or a utility, and zero otherwise; the Herfindahl‐Hirschman index, calculated as the sum of the squares of market shares for each industry year, where industries are defined by two‐digit SICs; and a regulatory supervision index.4I estimate temporal changes in the regulatory supervision of electric utilities by applying factor analysis to six observable electric utility regulatory variables, similar to Bryan, Hwang, and Thomas (1997). The variables I employ include nuclear operations, lines of business, incentive regulation and holding company indicator variables, the number of rate revenue approvals during the past five years, and the deregulation dummy variable. The nuclear operation variable is the proportion of sales attributable to nuclear power, scaled by total sales. Nuclear operations attract scrutiny by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, so higher proportions of nuclear to total sales are expected to be associated with closer regulatory monitoring. Nuclear data are taken from Moody’s Public Utilities Manuals. Number of lines of business is the number of segments reported in Compustat. The greater the number of lines of business, the more diversified and less regulated the utility. Incentive and holding company indicator variables are one if the firm is subject to comparatively invasive incentive regulation (as defined in Landon [1993]) or the 1934 Public Utility Holding Company Act, and zero otherwise. The greater the number of rate revenue approvals in the past five years, the more frequent and thus intense the state or local regulatory supervision of the utility. Factor coefficients are multiplied by firm‐year data for electric utilities and set to zero for industrial firms, to obtain the electric utility regulatory supervision index.

fn.p: I also perform a sensitivity analysis to assess the effects of using a Herfindahl‐Hirschman index based on a finer gradation of industry with a three‐digit instead of a two‐digit SIC definition of industry.

Growth opportunities are lower for utilities than for industrial firms and increase over time. The increase in growth opportunities among deregulating utilities is consistent with predictions in Smith and Watts (1992) but could be part of a trend among all firms toward more valuable growth opportunities.

Governance features of sample firms summarized in panel B oftable 1suggest that governance structures better control owner‐manager agency conflict both for utilities and for industrial firms after 1992. Median utility CEO ownership increases postderegulation from 0.03% to 0.05% of total equity outstanding, or from about $0.392 million to $0.766 million. Mean utility proportion of CEO pay in options increases from 3.78% to 8.42% of CEO pay. Median (mean) utility board size is approximately 11 directors (between 11.2 and 11.6 directors). Median (mean) proportion of outside directors increases from 72% to 78% (70%–76%) of board size. Median (mean) industrial proportion of outside blockholder ownership increases from 6.42% to 10.75% (9.87%–15.42%) of outstanding equity. Median (mean) proportion of CEO compensation paid in options increases from 13.27% to 37.67% (20.81%–35.26%) of total CEO pay, and median board size drops from 12 to 11 directors. Median (mean) industrial proportion of outside directors increases from 63% to 75% (61%–71%) of the board.

Product market competition statistics in panel C oftable 1suggest that utility and industrial firm industry concentration decreases (competition increases) post‐1992, and industry concentration remains greater (competition remains lower) for utilities than for industrial firms. The median (mean) Herfindahl‐Hirschman index for utilities decreases from 0.435 to 0.390 (0.429 to 0.344). The median (mean) Herfindahl‐Hirschman index for industrial firms decreases from 0.279 to 0.163 (0.304 to 0.195).

To estimate temporal changes in the degree of regulatory supervision, I perform factor analysis on six observable electric utility regulatory supervision variables. For the pooled utilities for 1987–97, a single common factor, regulatory supervision, explains 64.47% of the total variation. Only the first factor is retained because the proportion of total variance explained by additional factors is negligible. Panel A oftable 2shows that all input variables load on the common factor, with no one variable explaining most of the common variance. Factor loading coefficients are multiplied by firm‐year data to generate factor score values for each utility‐year observation or are set to zero for each industrial firm‐year observation because industrial firms are not directly affected by electric utility regulatory supervision. Panel B shows that the factor score is correlated with all six observable electric utility regulation variables in a manner that suggests that it estimates the degree of electric utility regulatory supervision. Panel C reports significant decreases in median and mean electric utility regulatory supervision, consistent with deregulation. However, rather than try to attribute economic meaning to electric utility regulatory supervision score levels, I focus on temporal changes in the regulatory supervision of electric utilities. sec.label: D.
sec.title: Methodology
sec.p:
In my multivariate analysis, I employ a two‐part study design. First, I use a traditional pre‐ versus postderegulation indicator variable to identify governance characteristics of utilities that exhibit change or trend‐adjusted change. Regressions applied only to utilities are of the form

The Dereg it coefficient captures changes among utilities in Gov it between the pre‐ and post‐1992 periods, after controls. Regressions applied to the full sample are of the form
where Util it is an electric utility dummy variable equal to one if the firm is an electric utility, and zero otherwise. Statistically significant interaction coefficients identify trend‐adjusted changes for utilities in Gov it between the pre‐ and post‐1992 periods, after controls. The Dereg it ×Util it coefficient captures trend‐adjusted changes among utilities relative to industrial firms. Fixed effects include firm and time dummy variables. Because common rather than total variation in governance characteristics may be the most relevant measure of the overall ability of governance structures to mitigate owner‐manager agency conflict, I also repeat these regressions using the governance indexes as dependent variables.5

In the second part of the analysis, I employ continuous estimates for product market competition and regulatory supervision to show that product market competition explains changes in electric utility governance following deregulation. where Gov it is a governance characteristic that changed, or one of the governance factor scores, HHI jt is the Herfindahl‐Hirschman index, and Regulation it is regulatory supervision, for firmiand industryjat timet. The HHI it coefficient reflects the association between changes in product market competition and Gov it that occur during the study period.6I perform sensitivity analysis to show that my results are robust to the definition of industry using a two‐ or three‐digit SIC. Finally, to show that competition increases for utilities, but more so for industrial firms, I perform two additional regressions that parallel those based on equations(1)and(2). In these regressions, I employ the Herfindahl‐Hirschman index as the dependent variable and the deregulation dummy, or the deregulation dummy interacted with the utility dummy, and regulatory supervision as independent variables.

fn.p: Factor analysis applied to all eight governance variables generates several common factors because of a high degree of correlation between several variables. The resulting factors could not be easily identified. However, factor analysis applied only to governance variables that change generates a single common factor for utilities or for utilities relative to industrial firms. When factor loading coefficients are multiplied by the data, the resulting factor indices are correlated with individual governance characteristic changes in a way that suggests that they measure the overall ability of governance structures to control owner‐manager agency conflict.

I do not include a takeover activity variable in these tests because there is little consensus how to measure takeover activity, takeover activity already affects industry concentration used to estimate product market competition, and there is little takeover activity among sample firms. Tests for a possible relation between governance structure changes and takeover activity in other industries are left for future research.

sec.label: IV.
sec.title: Deregulation and Changes in Governance Structure
sec.p: In this section, I show that utilities adopt governance structures that better control owner‐manager agency conflict after the 1992 Energy Policy Act. I also show that utilities do not enhance their governance structures by as much as industrial firms.

Results reported intable 4suggest weaker trend‐adjusted governance structure controls for owner‐manager agency conflict for utilities postderegulation, whereas Kole and Lehn (1999) report mixed trend‐adjusted governance changes for airlines. My decrease of 1.7% of outside blockholder ownership concentration for utilities relative to industrial firms compares with no change (or a 2.0% increase, depending on Kole and Lehn’s definition of outside blockholder ownership) for airlines relative to benchmark firms. sec.label: B.
sec.title: Changes in the Overall Effectiveness of Electric Utilities' Governance Structures
sec.p: I perform additional tests because common rather than total variation in governance characteristics of firms could capture the overall ability of governance structures to control owner‐manager agency conflict. Specifically, I apply factor analysis to individual governance features that change, first for utilities and then for utilities relative to industrial firms. Factor scores are generated by multiplying factor weights by firm‐year data. Factor scores are correlated with individual governance characteristics of firms in ways consistent with the interpretation that they estimate the overall ability of firms’ governance structures to control owner‐manager agency conflict. I generate the utility governance factor score by applying factor analysis to the governance characteristics shown intable 3to change, including proportion of CEO ownership, proportion of outside blockholder ownership, proportion of CEO compensation paid in options, board size, and proportion of outside directors on the board. Similarly, I generate the full sample governance factor score by applying factor analysis to governance characteristics shown intable 4to have exhibited trend‐adjusted change, including the proportion of outside blockholder ownership, proportion of CEO compensation awarded in options, and board size.

Results reported intable 5suggest that the utilities governance factor score and the full sample governance factor score estimate changes in the overall ability of governance structures to control owner‐manager agency conflict. Fifty‐one percent of total variation in electric utility governance characteristics that change is explained by the first factor for utilities. However, only 25% of the trend‐adjusted variation in electric utility governance characteristics is explained by the first factor for the full sample. Only the first factor is retained for utilities, and for utilities plus industrial firms, because additional factors explain negligible proportions of additional common variance. Panel A verifies that all variables load on the common factors and no one input variable explains a preponderance of total change. Correlation coefficients reported in panel B, with one exception, suggest that these factors estimate overall governance structure effectiveness for utilities and for utilities relative to industrial firms. Results are robust to the measurement of overall governance change as total or common variation in governance characteristics that change. The finding that deregulation is associated with governance structures that better mitigate owner‐manager agency conflict for utilities before controlling for industrial firm trends is consistent with theory and prior empirical evidence from the airline industry (Kole and Lehn1997,1999). It is also consistent with the deregulation effect hypothesis. However, the finding that deregulation is associated with relatively weaker internal agency control structures for utilities relative to industrial firms is inconsistent with this view. One explanation is that regulatory oversight complements the ability of governance structures to mitigate owner‐manager agency conflict. Alternatively, the traditional deregulation indicator variable may be a poor proxy for reduced regulatory monitoring because other important changes, such as increased competition, also occur.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Changes in Product Market Competition and Governance Structures
sec.p: In this section, I show that changes in governance structures of sample firms are associated with changes in product market competition. Evidence from regressions based onequation (3)is reported for specific governance structure characteristics and for overall governance index scores.

sec.title: Changes in Product Market Competition and Governance Structure Characteristics
sec.p:
Evidence on the association between changes in product market competition and changes in governance structure features of sample firms is reported intable 7. Predictions shown reflect the product market competition effect hypothesis that views electric utility deregulation as a catalyst for increased competition that pressures utilities to adopt governance structures that better control owner‐manager agency conflict. Predictions would be opposite to those shown if managers respond to increased competition by acting in shareholder interests to ensure firm and thus managerial survival, effectively reducing the need for governance structures to control owner‐manager agency conflict. Results reported in columns 1–5 oftable 7suggest that changes in individual governance characteristics of utilities are related to changes in product market competition. Specifically, boards of directors respond to increased competition by strengthening governance structures to ensure managers maximize value. Industry concentration is negatively related to each of the proportions of CEO ownership and outside blockholders and positively related to board size. Consequently, product market competition complements governance structures that mitigate owner‐manager agency conflict.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Sensitivity Analysis
sec.p: To assess whether the above results are sensitive to the use of a Herfindahl‐Hirschman index based on a broad two‐digit SIC industry definition, I repeat the second part of the analysis using a finer three‐digit SIC industry definition.7The median (mean) three‐digit SIC Herfindahl‐Hirschman Index decreases from 0.26 to 0.25 (0.38 to 0.26), and for industrial firms from 0.303 to 0.086 (4.77 to 0.125), with differences statistically significantly different from zero at the 1% level. This evidence resembles the results reported in panel C oftable 1for the two‐digit Herfindahl‐Hirschman index. It confirms that industry concentration decreases, and product market competition increases, for utilities and industrial firms after 1992.

Multivariate tests like those reported in tables7–9generate similar results whether a two‐ or three‐digit SIC Herfindahl‐Hirschman index is employed. For utilities, the three‐digit SIC Herfindahl‐Hirschman index coefficients in the CEO ownership and board size regressions are −0.054 and 14.288, statistically significant at the 1% level. Similarly, the three‐digit SIC Herfindahl‐Hirschman index coefficients in the proportions of outside blockholder ownership and CEO compensation in options regressions are −0.700 and −1.874, but the proportion of outside directors on boards is 0.496, significant at a 5% or better level. These results suggest that product market competition explains changes in individual governance characteristics, and competition complements individual governance characteristics of utilities that control agency conflict. For utilities relative to industrial firms, the three‐digit SIC Herfindahl‐Hirschman index coefficients in the proportions of outside blockholder ownership and CEO option grants regressions are −0.0789 and −0.141, and in the board size regression is 0.857. These results suggest that competition also explains changes in individual governance characteristics of utilities relative to industrial firms and confirm that competition complements individual governance characteristics of firms that control agency conflict. Similarly, the three‐digit SIC Herfindahl‐Hirschman index coefficients in the utilities and full‐sample governance index regressions are −7.762 and −0.376, statistically significant at the 1% level. These results show that competition explains overall governance structure changes of utilities and of utilities relative to industrial firms, and confirm that competition and governance characteristics of firms that control owner‐manager agency conflict are complements. Finally, tests resembling those reported intable 9show a change coefficient of −0.008 for utilities and a trend‐adjusted change coefficient of 0.343 for utilities relative to industrial firms, significant at the 1% level. These results show that industry concentration decreases, and thus product market competition increases, more for industrial firms than for utilities after 1992.
Consequently, the evidence continues to support the product market competition effect hypothesis. It also shows that competition increases more for industrial firms than for utilities post‐1992.

fn.p: To avoid contamination of the electric utility sample with nonelectric utility firms, I estimate the Herfindahl‐Hirschman index only for firms in SICs 4911 and 4931, as well as industrial firms in SICs 200–399. For example, SIC 4932 is gas and other services combined, and SIC 4939 is combination utilities not elsewhere classified. For brevity, tables are not included, but detailed results are available on request from the author.

sec.label: VI.
sec.title: Discussion and Conclusion
sec.p: Prior research (Crawford et al.1995; Hubbard and Palia1995; Bryan, Hwang, and Thomas1997; Kole and Lehn1997,1999; Bryan, Hwang, and Lilien1999) shows that deregulating firms tend to adopt governance structures that better control owner‐manager agency conflict. It does not detail the economic forces that underlie deregulation that cause governance structures to change. By differentiating between the effects of reduced regulatory monitoring and increased competition, this paper demonstrates that increased competition stemming from deregulation explains observed governance structure changes.

This paper shows that electric utilities adopt governance structures that better control owner‐manager agency conflict after deregulation. Electric utilities tend to increase the proportions of CEO and outside blockholder ownership, CEO pay in options, and outside directors on boards and reduce board size, suggesting governance structures that more closely control owner‐manager agency conflict. These results hold whether changes in overall governance are determined by total or common variation in individual governance characteristics that change. This evidence is consistent with the deregulation effect hypothesis that states that deregulation is accompanied by changes, and trend‐adjusted changes, in utility governance structures consistent with greater control over owner‐manager agency conflict. It is also consistent with Kole and Lehn’s (1999) discovery of the gradual adaptation of the governance structures of deregulating airlines toward those of nonregulated industrial firms.

This paper also finds that deregulating utilities do not strengthen their governance structures to control owner‐manager agency conflict as much as industrial firms. In particular, the proportions of outside blockholder ownership and CEO pay in options increase less, and board size decreases less, for utilities than for industrial firms. These results are also robust to the measurement of changes in overall governance structures based on total or common variation. This evidence is inconsistent with the deregulation effect hypothesis. It is consistent with Kole and Lehn’s (1999) finding of lower proportions of outside directors.

Importantly, this paper demonstrates that increases in product market competition that follow reductions in regulatory oversight explain observed changes in the governance structures of firms. Product market competition tends to be associated with greater proportions of CEO ownership and outside directors on boards and smaller boards for utilities. However, competition is also associated with relatively greater proportions of outside blockholder ownership and CEO pay in options and relatively smaller boards for industrial firms than utilities. The evidence is consistent with the product market competition effect hypothesis that states that electric utility deregulation introduces product market competition that pressures utilities to adopt governance structures that more closely control owner‐manager agency conflict.

Finally, this paper shows that product market competition increases less for utilities than for industrial firm’s post‐1992. The fact that the 1992 Energy Policy Act provides for only the partial deregulation of the U.S. electric utility industry explains competition increase differences between utilities and industrial firms. Governance structures of utilities change to provide greater control of owner‐manager agency conflict, but do not keep pace with similar, more pronounced changes among industrial firms. A more complete deregulation of electric utilities will likely further stimulate competition, leading to enhanced governance structures that better control owner‐manager agency conflict.
